questions.text: A one-year-old boy presents with lethargy, poor muscle tone, and developmental delays. Blood tests reveal elevated levels of glycine. The physician suspects a defect in the glycine cleavage system. Which of the following metabolites, if found LOW, would support the diagnosis of a defective glycine cleavage system?
questions.explanation:
Glycine Cleavage System

Location
  • Liver mitochondria

Function
  • Splits glycine into carbon dioxide, and ammonia, and forms N⁵, N¹⁰-methylenetetrahydrofolate (THFA).

Glycine Cleavage Complex
  • Composed of three enzymes and an H-protein.

Subunits
  • T: Tetrahydrofolate-dependent aminotransferase
  • P: Pyridoxal phosphate-dependent glycine decarboxylase
  • L: Lipoamide-dependent dehydrogenase
  • H: Hydrogen or electron transport system

Co-enzymes
  • Tetrahydrofolate (THF)
  • Pyridoxal phosphate (PLP)
  • Lipoamide

Reaction Mechanism
  • Glycine is broken down into CO₂, NH₄⁺, and a methylene group (–CH₂–).
  • The methylene group is transferred to THF, forming N⁵,N¹⁰-methylenetetrahydrofolate.

Reaction

Glycine + H₄-folate + NAD⁺ → CO₂ + NH₃ + 5,10-CH₂-H₄-folate + NADH + H⁺

Major Catabolic Pathway
  • The glycine cleavage system is the major catabolic route for glycine.

Associated Disorders
  • Nonketotic Hyperglycinemia: Accumulation of glycine in body tissues and CNS.
  • Primary Hyperoxaluria: Failure to break down glyoxylate leads to oxalate formation, kidney stones, and possible renal failure or hypertension.
  • Glycinuria: A defect in kidney reabsorption causes excessive glycine in urine.

questions.text: A patient with a urea cycle disorder is being evaluated. Which urea cycle intermediate serves as the link between the urea cycle and the TCA cycle?

A 3-week-old infant presents with poor feeding, lethargy, and vomiting. Lab results show elevated ammonia levels, increased glutamine and increased orotic acid in the blood, with no evidence of megaloblastic anaemia. Which enzyme deficiency is likely responsible for this condition?
Which enzyme in the histidine catabolism pathway facilitates incorporating the formimino group into the one-carbon pool, forming N5-formimino tetrahydrofolate?

Urocanate

2.

Urocanate

Urocanase (Option B)

Imidazole propionic acid

3.

Imidazole propionic acid

Hydrolase

Formiminoglutamate (FIGLU)

4.

FIGLU

Glutamate Formimino transferase (Option C)

L-Glutamate

5.

Glutamate

Glutamate dehydrogenase (Option D)

α-Ketoglutarate

questions.text: In the kynurenine pathway of tryptophan catabolism, which of the following compounds directly contributes to the formation of N10-formyl tetrahydrofolate in the one-carbon pool?
questions.explanation:
Compound

Role in Tryptophan Catabolism

Contribution

Formylkynurenine (Option A)

Intermediate; releases formate for N10-formyl THFA

Directly contributes to the formation of N10-formyl THFA

Kynurenine

(Option B)

Intermediate; precursor for other metabolites

Participates in the synthesis of other metabolites like quinolinic acid and nicotinic acid​.

3- Hydroxy kynurenine (Option C)

Intermediate; precursor for other metabolites

The product formed from formate derived from formylkynurenine

THFA

(Option D)

Carrier of one-carbon units

Not directly derived from tryptophan catabolism

questions.text: A 62-year-old female patient presents with fatigue, pallor, and glossitis. Laboratory tests indicate macrocytic anaemia, and elevated homocysteine and methylmalonic acid levels. Given these findings, what is the most likely metabolic pathway disrupted by this patient's condition, leading to the observed anaemia?

options.label: B
options.text: Reduction of folic acid to dihydrofolate

options.label: C
options.text: Deamination of histidine to formimino glutamate

questions.correct_answer: A. Conversion of homocysteine to methionine
questions.explanation:
Deficiency

Primary Effect

Biochemical Marker

Clinical Outcome

Vitamin B12

Impaired conversion of N5-methyl THF to THF

Elevated homocysteine and Methylmalonic acid

Megaloblastic anaemia, peripheral neuropathy

Folate

Reduced synthesis of THF from dietary folate forms

Accumulation of FIGLU in urine, Elevated homocysteine and normal Methylmalonic acid

Megaloblastic anemia

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding one-carbon derivatives of tetrahydrofolic acid (THFA) and their associated enzymes and reactions is incorrect?

options.label: B
options.text: N5-methyl-THFA carries the methyl group for converting homocysteine to methionine.

options.label: C
options.text: N5N10-methylene-THFA is required to synthesise thymidylate (dTMP) from deoxyuridylate (dUMP).

options.label: D
options.text: N10-formyl-THFA transfers formyl groups in pyrimidine synthesis.

questions.correct_answer: D. N10-formyl-THFA transfers formyl groups in pyrimidine synthesis.
questions.explanation:
One-Carbon Derivatives of THFA

Description

Source

Utilization

N5-formyl-THFA and N10-formyl-THFA

(Option D)

  

Carry a formyl group (-CHO)

  

Tryptophan
  • Synthesis of purine nucleotides, forming C2 of the purine ring.

N5-formimino-THFA (Option A)

Carries a formimino group (-CH=NH)

  

Histidine via FIGLU
  • Involved in the conversion of formiminoglutamate (FIGLU) to glutamate, a step in histidine catabolism; Enzyme: Formiminoglutamate hydrolase

N10-hydroxymethyl-THFA

Carries a hydroxymethyl group (-CH2OH)

  

Choline and betaine

  
 

N5, N10-methylene-THFA (Option C)

  

Carries a methylene group (-CH2-)

  

Serine via serine hydroxymethyl transferase, glycine
  • Glycine synthesis (conversion of serine to glycine),
  • Thymidine synthesis (conversion of dUMP to dTMP); Enzyme: Thymidylate synthase
 

N5-methyl-THFA

(Option B)

  

Carries a methyl group (-CH3)

  

All one-carbon units ultimately form N5-methyl-THFA.
  • Methionine synthesis (conversion of homocysteine to methionine); Enzyme: Methionine synthase
  • Precursor for S-adenosylmethionine (SAM) for various transmethylation reactions.

questions.text: Based on the image given below, what are the sites at which the marked steps of creatinine synthesis occur?

options.label: A
options.text: a- brain, b- liver, c- kidney

options.label: B
options.text: a- kidney, b- liver, c- muscle

options.label: C
options.text: a- liver, b- kidney, c- muscle

questions.correct_answer: B. a- kidney, b- liver, c- muscle
questions.explanation:
Steps

 

Enzyme

 

Site

1.

The Amidino group of arginine is transferred to glycine to form guanidinoacetic acid.

Amidotransferase

Kidney (a) and pancreas

2.

Guanidoacetic acid is Methylated by S-adenosyl methionine to form creatine.

Methyl transferase

Liver (b)

3.

Creatine is phosphorylated to creatine phosphate.

Creatine kinase

Muscle, brain and liver.

4.

Creatine phosphate may be converted to its anhydride, creatinine

Non- enzymatic

Muscle (c)

questions.text: Which of the following is not a known use of glycine in humans?

options.label: A
options.text: Precursor for metabolites like creatine, glutathione, and heme.

options.label: B
options.text: Enhances the quality of sleep and supports neurological functions.

options.label: C
options.text: Inhibits synthesis of bile acid, reducing lipid absorption.

options.label: D
options.text: Provide structural integrity for collagen structure.

questions.correct_answer: C. Inhibits synthesis of bile acid, reducing lipid absorption.
questions.explanation:
Uses of Glycine

1) Metabolic Functions:
  • Precursor for metabolites such as creatine, glutathione, heme, purines, and porphyrins. (Option A)
  • Vital for protein synthesis.
  • Plays a crucial role in collagen structure by occupying every third position in the collagen triple helix. (Option D)

2) Health and Disease Prevention:
  • Dietary supplementation can prevent or treat metabolic disorders in patients with cardiovascular diseases, inflammatory diseases, obesity, cancers, and diabetes.
  • Supports overall health, growth, and well-being in humans.

3) Neurological and Sleep Benefits:
  • Acts as a neurotransmitter in the central nervous system, influencing food intake, behaviour, and body homeostasis.
  • Enhances sleep quality and neurological functions. (Option B)

4) Immune Function:
  • Regulates immune responses by altering intracellular calcium levels.
  • Modulates the production of superoxide and cytokines.

5) Digestive Health:
  • Facilitates the conjugation of bile acids.
  • Aid in the absorption and digestion of lipid-soluble vitamins and lipids. (Option C)

questions.text: The glycine cleavage system in the body produces CO2, ammonia and a one-carbon molecule. Which of the following is a subunit in the system?
questions.explanation:
Subunits of the glycine cleavage system

Co-enzymes of glycine cleavage system

Tetrahydrofolate dependant aminotransferase (THFAAMT) (Option C)

THF (Option A)

Pyridoxal phosphate-dependant (PLP) glycine decarboxylase

Pyridoxal phosphate (PLP) (Option D)

Lipoamide dependent dehydrogenase

Lipoamide (Option B)

Hydrogen or electron transport system

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant presented with lethargy, vomiting, and irritability. Blood tests revealed elevated ammonia levels. The infant was diagnosed with a urea cycle disorder. Which of the following medications, acting as ammonia-scavenging agents, would be most effective in reducing the infant's blood ammonia levels?

A 45-year-old man presents to the clinic with complaints of fatigue and abdominal discomfort. Blood tests reveal elevated levels of alanine aminotransferase (ALT) and aspartate aminotransferase (AST). The physician suspects liver disease. Which of the following statements best describes the role of transamination reactions in amino acid metabolism?

options.label: A
options.text: Transfer an amino group to one keto acid, producing new amino and keto acids.

options.label: B
options.text: Specific to lysine, threonine, and proline.

options.label: C
options.text: Elevated AST and ALT indicate myocardial infarction.

options.label: D
options.text: Occur exclusively in the liver mitochondria.

questions.correct_answer: A. Transfer an amino group to one keto acid, producing new amino and keto acids.
questions.explanation:
Transamination Process
  • Transfer of an α-amino group from an amino acid to one keto acid, producing a new α-keto acid and a new amino acid. (Option A)
  • The first step is the catabolism of most amino acids.
  • All amino acids, except Proline, hydroxyproline, threonine, and lysine, participate in transamination. (Option B)

Biological Importance
  • Amino Acid Interconversion: Maintains balance of non-essential amino acids by transferring amino groups to synthesise needed amino acids.
  • Ammonia Disposal: Detoxifies ammonia by funnelling amino groups into glutamate, which is deaminated in the liver for excretion.

Glutamate's Role
  • α-Ketoglutarate: Acts as an acceptor of amino groups from most amino acids, converting to glutamate.
  • Transamination occurs in the cytoplasm; the amino group is transported to the liver as glutamate. (Option D)
  • Oxidative Deamination: Glutamate undergoes rapid oxidative deamination in the mitochondria to form α-ketoglutarate, which can accept another amino group.

Enzymes
  • Aminotransferases (Transaminases): Catalyse the transfer of amino groups between carbon skeletons. They are not coenzymes. (Option C)
  • Alanine Aminotransferase (ALT): Transfers amino group from alanine to α-ketoglutarate, forming pyruvate and glutamate.
  • Aspartate Aminotransferase (AST): Transfers amino groups from glutamate to oxaloacetate, forming aspartate used in the urea cycle.

Coenzyme
  • Pyridoxal Phosphate (PLP): Required by all aminotransferases, derived from vitamin B6.

Reversibility
  • Transamination reactions are reversible, with equilibrium constants near 1.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a source of glycine?
A 45-year-old male with microcytic anaemia is found to have a deficiency of a vitamin essential for the rate-limiting step of heme synthesis. Which vitamin is most likely deficient?

A 5-month-old boy presents with failure to thrive, developmental delay, and intermittent episodes of vomiting and lethargy. The episodes coincide with the introduction of solid foods. Blood tests reveal elevated ammonia levels and high levels of ornithine in blood. Urine analysis shows increased excretion of homocitrulline. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Hyperornithinemia-Hyperammonemia-Homocitrullinuria Syndrome

Inheritance

Autosomal recessive

Defective Gene

ORC1

Defective Protein

Mitochondrial Ornithine Transporter: This transporter moves ornithine into the mitochondria and citrulline out of the mitochondria.

Mechanism
  • Prevents ornithine from entering the mitochondria, which is necessary for the urea cycle.
  • The buildup of ammonia in the blood (hyperammonemia).
  • Ornithine also accumulates in the cytoplasm (hyperornithinemia).
  • Carbamoyl phosphate reacts with lysine to form homocitrulline.

Symptoms
  • Failure to thrive.
  • Developmental delay.
  • Intermittent episodes of vomiting and lethargy (triggered by protein intake).
  • Seizures.
  • Intellectual disability.

Diagnosis
  • Elevated blood ammonia
  • Elevated blood ornithine
  • Elevated urinary homocitrulline.

Treatment
  • Low-protein diet
  • Nitrogen scavenger medications
  • Liver transplant in severe cases.

questions.text: A 5-month-old male infant with a history of vomiting, irritability, and developmental delay. The onset of symptoms coincided with the introduction of formula feed. Physical examination revealed hepatomegaly and signs of encephalopathy. Blood tests revealed elevated ammonia levels and high glutamine, uracil, and orotic acid concentrations. Citrulline levels were normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Type 1 Hyperammonemia

Type 2 Hyperammonemia

Defective Enzyme

Carbamoyl Phosphate Synthetase I (CPS1)

Ornithine Transcarbamylase (OTC)

Inheritance

Autosomal recessive

X-linked recessive

Mechanism

The inability to synthesize carbamoyl phosphate blocks the urea cycle.

Accumulation of carbamoyl phosphate in the mitochondria, which then spills over into the cytoplasm.

Metabolic Consequences
  • Elevated ammonia and glutamate
  • Normal orotic acid and uracil
  • Low citrulline. (Option A)
  • Elevated ammonia, glutamate, and glutamine.
  • High uracil and orotic acid (excess carbamoyl phosphate enters pyrimidine synthesis).
  • Normal citrulline.

Clinical Presentation
  • Symptoms coincide with increased protein intake.
  • CNS: Lethargy, drowsiness, coma, Convulsions, vomiting, respiratory stimulation, hyperventilation.
  • Similar to Type 1.
  • Hepatomegaly.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about carbamoyl phosphate synthetases is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: CPS-I is activated by PRPP, and CPS-II is inhibited by UTP.

options.label: B
options.text: CPS-I is located in cytosol, and CPS-II in mitochondria.

options.label: C
options.text: CPS-I is involved in urea cycle, and CPS-II in pyrimidine synthesis.

options.label: D
options.text: Source of nitrogen for CPS-I is glutamine, and CPS-II is ammonia.

questions.correct_answer: C. CPS-I is involved in urea cycle, and CPS-II in pyrimidine synthesis.
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Carbamoyl Phosphate Synthetase-I (CPS-I)

Carbamoyl Phosphate Synthetase-II (CPS-II)

Site (Option B)

Mitochondria

Cytosol

Pathway involved (Option C)

Urea cycle

Pyrimidine synthesis

Source of Nitrogen (Option D)

Ammonia

𝛾-Amide group of glutamine

Positive effector (Option A)

N-acetyl glutamate

Phosphoribosyl pyrophosphate (PRPP)

Inhibitor

Nil

Uridine triphosphate(UTP)

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the rate-limiting step of the urea cycle?

options.label: A
options.text: It involves the formation of citrulline from ornithine.

options.label: B
options.text: It is catalysed by carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I (CPS I).

options.label: C
options.text: It is regulated by argininosuccinate synthetase.

options.label: D
options.text: It is controlled by the enzyme argininosuccinate lyase.

questions.correct_answer: B. It is catalysed by carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I (CPS I).
questions.explanation:
Reactions in the Urea Cycle

Step

Reaction Details

Enzyme Involved and Location

Key Points

Carbamoyl Phosphate Formation
  • Formation of carbamoyl phosphate from ammonia and CO₂ using ATP.
  • Carbamoyl Phosphate Synthetase I (CPS I)
 
  • Mitochondria
  • The rate-limiting step of the urea cycle.
  • Irreversible and allosterically regulated by N-acetyl glutamate (NAG).

Citrulline Formation (Option A)
  • Transfer of carbamoyl phosphate to ornithine to form citrulline.
  • Ornithine Transcarbamylase (OTC)
     
  • Mitochondria
  • Citrulline moves from mitochondria to cytosol for further processing in the urea cycle.

Argininosuccinate Formation (Option C)
  • Citrulline combines with aspartate to form argininosuccinate.
  • Argininosuccinate Synthetase
 
  • Cytoplasm
  • Requires ATP.
  • Links the urea cycle with the TCA cycle via aspartate.

Argininosuccinate Cleavage (Option D)
  • Cleavage of argininosuccinate into arginine and fumarate.
  • Argininosuccinate Lyase
 
  • Cytoplasm
  • Fumarate enters the TCA cycle, providing a connection between the urea cycle and other metabolic pathways.

Arginine Cleavage to Ornithine and Urea
  • Hydrolysis of arginine to produce ornithine and urea.
  • Arginase
 
  • Cytoplasm
  • Ornithine is recycled back into the urea cycle.
  • Urea is excreted by the kidneys, with some urea also entering the intestine.

Fate of Urea
  • Urea is transported to the kidneys, filtered, and excreted in urine.
  • Kidneys/ Intestine
  • Urea excretion is the final step, removing excess nitrogen from the body.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about ammonia transport is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Glutamine moves ammonia from liver to brain.

options.label: B
options.text: Alanine transports ammonia from liver to muscles.

options.label: C
options.text: Glutamine and alanine transport ammonia to the liver.

options.label: D
options.text: Alanine does not participate in ammonia transport.

questions.correct_answer: C. Glutamine and alanine transport ammonia to the liver.
questions.explanation:
Transporter

Formation Process

Source

Destination

Mechanism/Role

Glutamine

Formed from glutamate and ammonia by glutamine synthetase.

Skeletal muscle, liver, CNS

Liver, kidneys
  • Transports ammonia from the brain and intestine to the liver. In the liver, glutamine is cleaved by glutaminase to release ammonia and glutamate.
  • Glutamate is then deaminated by glutamate dehydrogenase (GDH), releasing additional ammonia, which enters the urea cycle for detoxification.

Alanine

Formed from pyruvate and ammonia in muscles during the glucose-alanine cycle.

Muscles

Liver
  • Transports ammonia from muscle to the liver. In the liver, alanine is transaminated by alanine transaminase (ALT) to form pyruvate and glutamate.
  • The pyruvate is used to synthesize glucose, and the glutamate can be deaminated by GDH to release ammonia for the urea cycle.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with elevated ammonia levels presents with confusion and disorientation. Which of the following is not a typical symptom of ammonia toxicity?
questions.explanation:
Hyperammonemia

  • Occurs in advanced liver disease and certain genetic disorders of amino acid metabolism.
  • It can lead to loss of consciousness, coma, convulsions and may be fatal.
  • This is due to:
  1. Depletion of α-ketoglutarate from the citric acid cycle to form glutamate and glutamine.
  2. Reduced ATP production.
  3. Inhibition of α-ketoglutarate and pyruvate dehydrogenases by elevated ammonia levels.

Neurotoxic effects of hyperammonemia
  • Tremors (Option B)
  • Slurred speech (Option A)
  • Drowsiness
  • Vomiting
  • Cerebral edema
  • Blurred vision (Option D)
  • Potential coma and death

Causes

  • Genetic causes: Urea cycle disorders and organic acidurias
  • Hepatic encephalopathy
  • Cor pulmonale
  • Pulmonary emphysema
  • Renal failure

Management
  • Low-protein/high-calorie diet
  • Antibiotics to reduce bacterial load ( ￬ urease-producing bacteria)
  • Lactulose to decrease intestinal ammonia production

questions.text: Which of the following pathways is primarily involved in the detoxification of ammonia in the brain?

options.label: A
options.text: Conversion of ammonia to urea in neurons

options.label: B
options.text: Direct excretion of ammonia through the blood-brain barrier

options.label: C
options.text: Conversion of ammonia to glutamine via glutamine synthetase in astrocytes

options.label: D
options.text: Storage of ammonia in neurons as glutamate

questions.correct_answer: C. Conversion of ammonia to glutamine via glutamine synthetase in astrocytes

questions.text: Which of the following reactions is not catalysed by glutamate dehydrogenase (GDH)?

options.label: A
options.text: Conversion of α-ketoglutarate and ammonia to glutamate

options.label: C
options.text: Formation of aspartate from oxaloacetate and ammonia

questions.correct_answer: C. Formation of aspartate from oxaloacetate and ammonia

questions.text: Which of the following pairs of amino acids do not undergo transamination reactions?
questions.explanation:
Amino Acid

Reason

Proline
  • Has a secondary amino group within its pyrrolidine ring structure.
  • It cannot participate in standard transamination due to its structural characteristics.

Hydroxyproline
  • Derived from proline through post-translational modification; shares the same structural limitation.

Lysine
  • Has an epsilon-amino group in its side chain, which can form Schiff bases, potentially interfering with transamination.

Threonine
  • Loses its α-amino group through deamination rather than transamination.
  • Direct transamination does not occur; instead, it is converted to alpha-ketobutyric acid.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with confusion and lethargy. Blood tests show elevated levels of ammonia, suggesting hyperammonemia. Further tests indicate liver dysfunction. Which of the following best describes the process of oxidative deamination in amino acid metabolism?

options.label: A
options.text: Removal of an amino group from an amino acid, resulting in the corresponding keto acid and ammonia.

options.label: B
options.text: Involves only transamination reactions in the cytoplasm.

options.label: C
options.text: Generates ammonia, which is directly excreted by the kidneys.

options.label: D
options.text: Predominantly occurs in the liver cytoplasm, producing glutamine.

questions.correct_answer: A. Removal of an amino group from an amino acid, resulting in the corresponding keto acid and ammonia.
